issues.text: whether the three alleged eye witnesses, Zora Singh, P.W. 3, and Surjit Singh, P.W. 4, and Bachan Singh, P.W. 5, who are related to each other and the victims, as stated above could be relied upon, when corroborated by other facts and circumstances which may appear in the case, to sustain the conviction

anchor.surface_text: The whole question before the Courts was whether the three alleged eye witnesses, Zora Singh, P.W. 3, and Surjit Singh, P.W. 4, and Bachan Singh, P.W. 5, who are related to each other and the victims, as stated above could be relied upon, when corroborated by other facts and circumstances which may appear in the case, to sustain the conviction, The prosecution case was that Gian Singh and Zora Singh had gone to their field for watering their sugarcane crop in it on the evening of 18th June, 1969.

issues.text: should we, even if we do not entirely agree with the reasoning of the High Court, substitute our own views and reverse an order of acquittal by it

anchor.surface_text: The question raised before us is should we, even if we do number entirely agree with the reasoning of the High Court, substitute our own views and reverse an order of acquittal by it ? It is enough to refer to the State of Madras Vs. A. Vaidyanatha Iyer 2  to point out that this Courts power of interference under Article 136 of the Constitution with Judgments of acquittal is number exercised on principles which are different from those adopted by it in dealing with convictions.

issues.text: whether Zora Singh must have become unconscious before he could see and recognise his assailants

anchor.surface_text: The High Court thought that it was likely that Zora Singh would have become unconscious after receiving injuries before he could recognise his assailants. The High Court had also attached importance to the fact that nospecial report of the occurrence was proved to have been sent to a Magistrate. It has considered the explanation that this was due to the fact that the F.I.R. disclosed only offences punishable under Sections 307 and 326 I.P.C.

issues.text: whether the High Court's approach is vitiated by some basically erroneous apparent assumption or it adopts reasoning which, on the face of it, is unsound

anchor.surface_text: If, however, the High Courts approach is vitiated by some basically errcneous apparent assumption or it adopts reasoning which, on the face of it, is unsound, it may- become the duty of this Court, to prevent a miscarriage of justice, to interfere with an order whether it be of conviction or of acquittal. In the case before us, the Trial Court, which had the additional advantage of seeing the witnesses depose in the witness box, had accepted the testimony of the three eye witnesses, despite the fact that they are relations of the victims.

issues.text: whether the respondents committed offences under Sections 302/34 IPC

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, set aside the order of acquittal by the High Court and convict the respondents for the offences with which they were charged. As, however, the occurrence took place several years ago, we refrain from awarding a death sentence in this case. We sentence both Hari Singh respondent u s 302 I.P.C. and Gian Singh respondent sons of Arjan Singh to life imprisonment under Sections 302/34 P.C.

issues.text: whether the respondents committed offences under Sections 307/34 IPC

anchor.surface_text: We also sentence each of them to six years rigorous imprisonment and to pay a fine of Rs. 2,000/- each, and, in default of payment of fine, to rigorous imprisonment for a further period of two years under Sections 307/34 I.P.C.

arguments.claim: The three eye-witnesses Zora Singh PW3, Surjit Singh PW4, and Bachan Singh PW5 are reliable and their testimony sustains conviction when corroborated by other facts.

arguments.claim: Bachan Singh and Surjit Singh unlikely to remain at sugarcane field or be awake at midnight as watering was completed.

anchor.surface_text: He had stated in his evidence that one or two bighas of sugarcane can be irrigated in an hour by their Tubewell. Watering was said to have commenced at p.m. and Zora Singh, P.W. 3, had stated that only 4 bighas of the field had to be watered. The High Court, therefore, did not think it likely that either Bachan Singh or Surjit Singh would still remain at the Sugarcane field or be awake at the time when the occurrence took place.

arguments.court_reasoning: No evidence they were elsewhere; they arranged transport to hospital before day-break.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, the High Court thought that both Bachan Singh and Surjit Singh were too far away, at about 100 karams, to be able to reach in time to see the occurrence.

arguments.claim: Zora Singh would have run away or cried out earlier if awake when seeing assailants.

anchor.surface_text: It had observed that Zora Singh, aged only about 16 years, would have tried to run away as soon as he saw four assailants by electric light attacking Gian Singh only at a distance of 10 feet, if he was really awake.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: st the escaping assailants out of whom they recognised two. As human testimony, resulting from widely different powers of observation and description,

arguments.court_reasoning: Unreasonable assumption; injuries show sequence of attack allowing recognition.

arguments.claim: Zora Singh's statement about getting up to urinate is an improvement.

anchor.surface_text: It had also observed that he would have cried out earlier than the moment of time when he received the injury on his right arm if he was actually awake when the assault on Gian Singh, deceased, took place. It was not disposed to rely upon the statement of Zora Singh that he was lying awake because he had got up to urinate 5 minutes before the occurrence as this appeared to it to be an improvement upon his previous statement.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: doubt the Courts are bound. to give effect to the result flowing from it and number throw it overboard on purely hypothetical and companyjectural grou

arguments.court_reasoning: Ordinary presumption of truthfulness; explained as not questioned earlier.

arguments.claim: Zora Singh disclaimed knowledge of Milkiat and Dalip Singh despite adjoining fields.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had doubted the veracity of Zora Singh because he disclaimed knowledge that Milkiat Singh and Dalip Singh were employed in the Air Force although their fields adjoined his own fields.

arguments.claim: Zora Singh likely unconscious before recognizing assailants.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court thought that it was likely that Zora Singh would have become unconscious after receiving injuries before he could recognise his assailants.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: st the escaping assailants out of whom they recognised two. As human testimony, resulting from widely different powers of observation and description,

arguments.court_reasoning: Utterly unsupported by evidence; injuries and medical show he was struck first on arm, saw assailants; electric light present.

arguments.claim: No special report sent to Magistrate indicates fabrication.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had also attached importance to the fact that no special report of the occurrence was proved to have been sent to a Magistrate. It has considered the explanation that this was due to the fact that the F.I.R. disclosed only offences punishable under Sections 307 and 326 I.P.C. to be insufficient to explain this omission.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: o be wholly, companypletely and, unqualifiedly accepted. We think that the High Court had, without saying so, ignored the principle repeatedly laid do

arguments.court_reasoning: FIR discloses only 307/326 as victim alive; lodged soon after 5am; no indication of conspiracy.

arguments.claim: Prosecution must traverse gap between 'may be true' and 'must be true'.

anchor.surface_text: After relying upon the observations of this Court in Sarwan Singh Rattan Singh Vs. State of Punjab that the prosecution must traverse the whole gap between what may be true and what must be true before a conviction could be recorded in a criminal case, the High Court had given the respondents the benefit of doubt and acquitted them.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the evidence of Zora Singh appear to us to be patently unreasonable and highly companyjectural, we think that the case before us calls for interferenc

arguments.court_reasoning: Prosecution evidence separates chaff from grain, residue proves beyond doubt.

arguments.claim: Eyewitnesses reliable despite relationship; scrutinize closely but accept if no others available.

anchor.surface_text: It has been repeatedly held by this Court that the mere fact that a witness is related to the victim could not be a good enough ground for rejecting his testimony although it may be a ground for scrutinizing his evidence more critically and carefully where facts and circumstances disclose that only relations have been produced

arguments.claim: SC can interfere with acquittal if HC approach vitiated by erroneous assumption or unsound reasoning.

anchor.surface_text: Article 136 of the Constitution with Judgments of acquittal is not exercised on principles which are different ... If, however, the High Courts approach is vitiated by some basically erroneous apparent assumption or it adopts reasoning which, on the face of it, is unsound, it may become the duty of this Court, to prevent a miscarriage of justice, to interfere

arguments.claim: Explanation for omitting Milkiat and Dalip from FIR: Zora unconscious before communicating names.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution had an explanation for this omission. This was that Zora Singh, who had seen and recognised these two accused persons had become unconscious before their names could be communicated to Surjit Singh.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: l evidence and there is numberhing on record which companyflicts with this inference, it becomes evident that he must have shouted for help. If that b

arguments.court_reasoning: HC accepted Zora unconscious; consistent with prosecution version.

arguments.claim: Courts must separate chaff from grain in witness testimony.

anchor.surface_text: Courts must try to extract and separate the hard core of truth from the whole evidence. This is what is meant by the proverbial saying that Courts must separate the chaff from the grain.

arguments.claim: Courts do not act on falsus in uno falsus in omnibus.

anchor.surface_text: Courts do not, in this country, act on the maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus.

arguments.claim: Recoveries unreliable due to delay after arrest and possible 3rd degree methods.

anchor.surface_text: It had not relied upon the alleged recoveries ... As the recovery was shown to have taken place 4 days after the arrest of the respondents, the Trial Court thought that it must have resulted from the use of 3rd degree methods during the interrogation of the accused.

arguments.court_reasoning: SC convicts without relying on recoveries.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court had, however, relied upon the circumstance that the respondents could not be found when searched in their village and could only be arrested several days later.

arguments.claim: Zora Singh's evidence corroborated by medical evidence and injuries sequence.

anchor.surface_text: His account, that he was struck first on the arm and then he cried out, is corroborated by the fact that other injuries indicate that his face and jaw were aimed at and struck probably in an attempt to silence him. The injuries were of such a nature that he must have been awakened, shouted, writhed in pain, and seen the assailants before he became unconscious.

arguments.claim: FIR lodged promptly at 5.15am, before death, explaining sections 307/326.

anchor.surface_text: A First Information Report of this occurrence was lodged at 5.15 a.m. at Police Station Sadar, Ludhiana, ... disclosing offences punishable under Sections 307 and 326 Indian Penal Code only as Gian Singh was still alive, at that time.

arguments.court_reasoning: Indicates no fabrication; names of two respondents included, others described.

holdings.text: If, however, the High Courts approach is vitiated by some basically erroneous apparent assumption or it adopts reasoning which, on the face of it, is unsound, it may become the duty of this Court, to prevent a miscarriage of justice, to interfere with an order whether it be of conviction or of acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: If, however, the High Courts approach is vitiated by some basically errcneous apparent assumption or it adopts reasoning which, on the face of it, is unsound, it may- become the duty of this Court, to prevent a miscarriage of justice, to interfere with an order whether it be of conviction or of acquittal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Citing precedent under Article 136, SC interferes only if HC's approach fundamentally flawed to prevent miscarriage of justice.

holdings.text: the mere fact that a witness is related to the victim could not be a good enough ground for rejecting his testimony although it may be a ground for scrutinizing his evidence more critically and carefully where facts and circumstances disclose that only relations have been produced

anchor.surface_text: It has been repeatedly held by this Court that the mere fact that a witness is related to the victim companyld number be a good enough ground for rejecting his testimony although it may be a ground for scrutinizing his evidence more critically and carefully where facts and circumstances disclose that only relations have been produced

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repeatedly held by SC; relationship requires scrutiny but not outright rejection, especially if no independent witnesses.

holdings.text: we certainly do not find it possible to accept the view adopted by the High Court [that Zora Singh became unconscious before recognising assailants]

anchor.surface_text: On the last mentioned point, we certainly do number find it, possible to accept the view adopted by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: HC view unsupported by evidence; injuries sequence, electric light, and medical evidence corroborate Zora seeing assailants first.

holdings.text: Courts must try to extract and separate the hard core of truth from the whole evidence. This is what is meant by the proverbial saying that Courts must separate the chaff from the grain.

anchor.surface_text: the Courts must try to extract and separate the hard companye of truth from the whole evidence. This is what is meant by the proverbial saying that Courts must separate the chaff from the grain.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle for appraising evidence: sift true from false parts to find residue proving case beyond doubt.

holdings.text: Courts do not, in this country, act on the maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus.

anchor.surface_text: Courts do number, in this companyntry, act on the maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repeated SC principle; evaluate each part of testimony in context of whole evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eyewitness testimony of Zora Singh corroborated by medical evidence and circumstances proves guilt under 302/34 beyond doubt; HC erred in rejecting.

holdings.text: We also sentence each of them to six years rigorous imprisonment and to pay a fine of Rs. 2,000/- each, and, in default of payment of fine, to rigorous imprisonment for a further period of two years under Sections 307/34 I.P.C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same evidence establishes attempt to murder Zora Singh under 307/34; restores trial court conviction.

holdings.text: the F.I.R. discloses only offences punishable under Sections 307 and 326 I.P.C. indicates that it must have been lodged before 6 a.m... the alleged suspected delay in the lodging of the F.I.R. or in sending a special report to a Magistrate do not, on the facts of this case, indicate an attempt to conspire and fabricate.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the fact that the I.R. discloses only offences punishable under Sections 307 and 326 I.P.C. indicates that it must have been lodged before,6. a.m. In any event, before the Inquest report on the morning of 19-6-1969, the police had before it the. prosecution version companytained in the F.I.R.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prompt FIR before death explains sections; no conspiracy as names included selectively; rejects HC suspicion.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, set aside the order of acquittal by the High Court and convict the respondents for the offences with which they were charged. As, however, the occurrence took place several years ago, we refrain from awarding a death sentence in this case. We sentence both Hari Singh respondent u s 302 I.P.C. and Gian Singh respondent sons of Arjan Singh to life imprisonment under Sections 302/34 P.C. We also sentence each of them to six years rigorous imprisonment and to pay a fine of Rs. 2,000/- each

outcome.relief_summary: Set aside High Court order of acquittal and convicted the respondents under Sections 302/34 IPC and 307/34 IPC; sentenced both to life imprisonment under 302/34 IPC (refraining from death sentence) and six years rigorous imprisonment with Rs. 2,000 fine each (default 2 years RI) under 307/34 IPC

anchor.surface_text: If, however, the High Courts approach is vitiated by some basically errcneous apparent assumption or it adopts reasoning which, on the face of it, is unsound, it may- become the duty of this Court, to prevent a miscarriage of justice, to interfere with an order whether it be of conviction or of acquittal.

We, therefore, set aside the order of acquittal by the High Court and convict the respondents for the offences with which they were charged. As, however, the occurrence took place several years ago, we refrain from awarding a death sentence in this case. We sentence both Hari Singh respondent u s 302 I.P.C. and Gian Singh respondent sons of Arjan Singh to life imprisonment under Sections 302/34 P.C. We also sentence each of them to six years rigorous imprisonment and to pay a fine of Rs. 2,000/- each
